PostValue.explanation: This is a well-sourced, up-to-date synthesis of the global health landscape and financing that is useful background for donors, career-choosers, and EA practitioners considering health / development priorities. It helps calibrate scale (e.g. ~$10T health system, small share of external aid, rise of NCDs, large returns to basic spending in poor countries) and highlights practical levers (domestic financing, aid dependence, cost-effectiveness opportunities). However, it is primarily summary/context rather than presenting novel, load-bearing arguments or high-stakes normative claims: its conclusions won’t dramatically shift core EA/longtermist frameworks or global policy on their own, and errors would mostly affect calibration rather than foundational priorities.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Missing the most decision-relevant frame: marginal impact / cost‑effectiveness. The post gives useful aggregate spending and burden statistics, but readers (especially EA-minded ones) need guidance on how to translate those facts into priority decisions. Add a short, explicit section (4–6 sentences) explaining that total spending and total deaths are not the same as cost‑effectiveness or marginal benefit, and flag the standard metrics to use (DALYs/QALYs averted, cost per DALY, tractability/neglectedness). Give 2–3 quick examples of high‑ROI interventions (e.g., insecticide‑treated nets, childhood immunisation, vitamin A, seasonal malaria chemoprevention) with citations or links to GiveWell/DCP3/IHME so readers can immediately see how spending compares to outcomes.

2) Unclear definitions and sourcing could mislead readers. Key numbers ("~$10 trillion global health system", "74% of deaths from NCDs", donor shares, OOP figures) need explicit, inline citations and brief caveats about methodology and years. Define what you mean by "global health spending" (healthcare vs public health vs development assistance), and note major measurement limitations (purchasing power adjustments, health vs healthcare spending distinctions). Action: annotate every headline stat with its primary source and year and add one sentence about measurement caveats so readers don’t overgeneralise.

3) Overlooked but important force‑multipliers and counterarguments around donor dynamics and allocation. The post understates how donor priorities, vertical funding, and transition dynamics shape outcomes — and it risks implying that because external aid is a small share globally it’s unimportant. Add a brief paragraph (3–5 sentences) on: (a) how external aid can still be highly influential in LICs (examples: HIV/TB/malaria programs, Gavi/PEPFAR), (b) issues with sustainability/transition (donor withdrawal, borrowing), and (c) how funding modality (vertical vs health systems strengthening) affects long‑term impact. This will prevent the common misread that "aid is small so it doesn't matter" and give readers a clearer sense of where donations or advocacy can be most leverageable.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Very useful. The feedback pinpoints three substantive weaknesses that matter for an EA audience: the absence of an explicit marginal‑impact / cost‑effectiveness frame (which is essential for translating aggregate stats into priorities), the lack of precise inline sourcing and methodological caveats for headline numbers (risking misinterpretation), and missing nuance on donor dynamics (risking the misleading takeaway that external aid is unimportant). Each suggested fix is specific and short (a few sentences and a couple of examples/links), so would materially improve decision‑relevance and credibility without bloating the post. The only reason not to give a 10 is that the post isn’t fundamentally wrong—these are strong but corrective enhancements rather than emergency fixes.

PostClarity.explanation: Overall the post is clear and well‑structured: logical headings, bullets, figures and links make the material easy to navigate and the data-driven approach helps comprehension. Strengths include comprehensive coverage of major areas, clear statistics and useful links/visuals. Weaknesses: it is long and somewhat repetitive, occasionally dense with jargon and numbers (which could overwhelm casual readers), and the opening promise to emphasise the "funding side" isn’t always tightly focused — a concise executive summary and tighter signposting of the main takeaway(s) would improve argument clarity and conciseness.

PostNovelty.explanation: This post is a well‑sourced synthesis of widely available facts and statistics about global health (GBD, WHO, Our World in Data, health spending breakdowns, common thematic areas). It doesn’t propose new theories, models, or surprising empirical findings — mostly compiles and contextualises existing public data (e.g. ~$10T global spending, donor share, NCDs now dominating deaths). For EA Forum readers this is largely background/common knowledge (hence very low novelty). For the general educated public it’s a useful consolidated overview but still not original research or novel claims — modestly informative but not novel.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is well-structured and logical for an overview — it covers major disease areas, financing mechanisms, and high-level relationships (e.g. spending vs life expectancy, rising share of NCDs). It generally distinguishes contexts (low vs high income) and flags where external aid matters. Weaknesses: A few causal claims are presented too simply (e.g. income→health spending as purely causal) and there is limited critical discussion of countervailing effects or uncertainty. Evidence is drawn from reputable sources (Our World in Data, WHO, GBD) and includes many useful statistics, but many specific numbers lack precise citations/dates and some claims (e.g. exact donor-share thresholds by GDP per capita) are stated without direct sourcing or methodological caveats. Overall the post provides a solid, well-supported high-level summary suitable for orientation, but it is not a rigorous or exhaustive evidence review and would benefit from more explicit sourcing and nuance on causality and marginal returns.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Overall the post is largely accurate and draws on standard, reputable sources (WHO, IHME/GBD, FAO/UN, UNAIDS, Lancet). Major high-level claims — global health spending ≈US$9.8T (~10% of GDP), NCDs ≈74% of deaths, steep inequalities in health outcomes, key WASH/nutrition/maternal/child figures, and the composition of financing (domestic public ≈62%, private ≈37% with the US a very large share) — are supported by WHO and other authoritative data. A few numeric details are ambiguous or depend on definitions/timeframes: (1) the post’s diarrhoeal-deaths figure (~830k) differs from recent GBD/IHME estimates (≈1.2 million in 2021) and from WHO child-specific estimates (~444k under‑5 diarrhoea deaths); (2) the statement that “external aid constitutes 0.3% ($27.8b) of global health expenditure” depends on how “external aid” is defined (IHME’s DAH estimates are substantially larger when measured as development assistance for health disbursements — e.g., dozens of billions); (3) the mental‑health “≈14% of global burden” likely reflects share of YLDs (~14.6%) rather than total DALYs (mental disorders ≈4.9% of global DALYs in GBD 2019). These are minor/typical issues of metric choice and vintage rather than wholesale factual errors. Overall: well‑supported but with several place‑specific numbers that should be footnoted to the exact dataset and year when used for decision‑making.
